Portal, with it's odd sense of humor and almost faceless antagonist, the dialouge in the game eventually grows on you, maintaining it's humor up until the very end of the game.

I was slow to get on the Portal bandwagon, and at first I didn't think I'd like it (I'm more a hack-and-slash than a puzzle/strategy player) but once I got into the swing of things, I enjoyed it a lot.  It's definitely a unique game, and figuring out how best to use the portals to achieve objectives was challenging without being too frustrating. There's often no one way to beat each test - sometimes you need to be creative, other times you have to plan ahead, but most of all you have to be patient and think things through.  Yeah, doesn't sound like a load of laughs, but trust me, it's easy to get caught up.  Storywise, one word: GLaDOS.  Her character is hilarious and her commentary and rampant homicidal tendencies bring extra life to what might otherwise be a slightly tedious game.  So try out the bandwagon, whatever your usual preferences - you might love this game as much as I do now.  (Yes, I'm on my way straight to the sequel).

So there's this crazy voice. And this voice tells you what to do. It tells you to pick up a gun and shoot balls of blue and orange light. These lights make portals that break the space-time continuum. Or something. You don't know, you just solve puzzles to survive. You just shoot portals. And after you shoot more portals, you shoot some more portals. And then you find out that the voice wants you to do more then just shoot portals, it wants you to SURVIVE. Did I mention there are portals?
